content.title: Digital Eye Strain and the 20-20-20 Rule
content.summary: Understanding computer vision syndrome from prolonged screen use at conferences and evidence-based prevention strategies
key_points: Digital eye strain affects 50-90% of computer users - universal at tech conferences
Symptoms: eye fatigue, dryness, blurred vision, headache, neck/shoulder pain
Blink rate drops from 15/min to 5/min when viewing screens - causing dry eyes
20-20-20 rule: Every 20 minutes, look at something 20 feet away for 20 seconds
Screen position should be 20-26 inches away, slightly below eye level
Blue light filtering has limited evidence for strain but may help sleep if used evening
Room lighting should match screen brightness (not brighter than screen)

statement.text: Digital eye strain (computer vision syndrome) is a complex of ocular and visual symptoms resulting from prolonged near-focus work on digital screens. At conferences with presentations, phone checking, and networking apps, cumulative screen time often exceeds 10+ hours daily. The 20-20-20 rule and proper ergonomics can significantly reduce symptoms.
statement.formal: Eye Strain = f(Screen_Time × Near_Focus × Reduced_Blink_Rate × Poor_Lighting) - Preventive_Interventions

explanation.intuition: Your eyes aren't designed for hours of staring at glowing rectangles 2 feet away. When focusing on screens, your eye muscles stay contracted (like holding a weight), you blink less (drying your eyes), and you receive unnatural light patterns. The 20-20-20 rule is like putting down the weight briefly - relaxing the focus muscles by looking far away.
explanation.key_insight: The reduced blink rate is a major culprit often overlooked. We normally blink 15-20 times per minute, spreading tears evenly. During concentrated screen work, this drops to 3-5 times per minute, causing the tear film to break up and symptoms of dryness, grittiness, and fatigue.

definitions_glossary.digital_eye_strain: Ocular and visual symptoms from prolonged digital device use; also called computer vision syndrome
definitions_glossary.computer_vision_syndrome: Medical term for eye strain from computer use; includes both eye symptoms and musculoskeletal effects
definitions_glossary.accommodation: Eye's ability to adjust focus from far to near; prolonged near focus causes fatigue
definitions_glossary.accommodative_spasm: Temporary inability to relax focus muscles after prolonged near work
definitions_glossary.tear_film: Thin layer of moisture protecting cornea; disrupted by reduced blinking
definitions_glossary.blue_light: High-energy visible light (400-500nm) emitted by screens; may affect circadian rhythm
definitions_glossary.ergonomics: Science of fitting workplace conditions to worker capabilities

pathophysiology.mechanism: Near focus sustained → Ciliary muscle fatigue → Accommodative strain. Reduced blinking → Tear film instability → Ocular surface desiccation → Corneal exposure → Discomfort and blur. Glare and reflections → Pupillary strain → Headache

accommodative: Blurred vision at near or far

risk_factors: Poor screen positioning (too close, too high)
Dry indoor environments (air conditioning, low humidity)

20_20_20_rule.mechanism: Relaxes ciliary muscles, prompts blinking, resets focus

workstation_setup.height: Top of screen at or slightly below eye level
workstation_setup.lighting: Room lighting should match screen brightness
workstation_setup.glare: Position screen to avoid window reflections; use matte screen filter

blink_strategies: Consciously blink fully every few minutes
additional_measures: Increase text size/zoom to reduce squinting
Use dark mode in low-light environments
Take breaks to look at distant objects
Consider blue light filtering for evening screen use (sleep benefit)

definition.@value: Eye and vision-related problems resulting from prolonged digital device use, and the evidence-based 20-20-20 prevention strategy

learning_objectives: Understand the causes of digital eye strain
Optimize workstation ergonomics for eye health
Recognize when to seek professional eye care
Distinguish evidence-based interventions from marketing claims
practical_tips: Find distant focal point in conference venue for breaks
Carry artificial tears for air-conditioned venues
Adjust phone font size before conference
Sit where you can see windows for natural focus shifts
